case_vignette: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a painless lump on her neck for 3 months that has increased in size. She appears healthy. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, irregular swelling on the left side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neck shows a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. A fine needle aspiration biopsy is scheduled for the following week.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless lump on my neck that has been growing for 3 months, and it moves when I swallow.
Have you noticed any changes in your voice or difficulty swallowing recently?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my voice or difficulty swallowing.
Do you have any history of radiation exposure to your head or neck?
I do not have any history of radiation exposure to my head or neck.
Do you have a history of thyroid problems in your family?
I didn't mention any family history of thyroid problems.
Have you experienced any changes in your weight, heart rate, or energy levels recently?
No, I have not experienced any changes in my weight, heart rate, or energy levels recently.
Have you undergone any medical imaging, like an ultrasound, for your neck lump?
Yes, I had an ultrasound of my neck which showed a mass in the left side of my thyroid with increased blood flow and small bright spots inside it.
Final Diagnosis: Thyroid cancer
